verses.text: Call now: will any one answer? To which of the saints wilt thou turn?
For vexation killeth the fool, Indignation slayeth the simpleton.
I have seen a fool taking root, But his branch became suddenly rotten,
His children were far from help, Crushed beyond hope deliverance.
The hungry eat up their harvest, And the thirsty draw from their wells.
For not from the dust riseth ruin, Nor out of the ground springeth trouble;
But man is born unto trouble, While the sons of flame soar above it.
Were it I, I would seek unto God; My cause I would bring before God,
Who doeth great things and unsearchable, Marvellous things without number,
Who bringeth rain over the earth, And over the fields sendeth water–
Setting the lowly on high, And lifting the mourners to safety,
Frustrating the plots of the crafty And robbing their hands of success,
So taking the wise in their guile, That their tortuous plans fail through rashness:
They feel in the day as in darkness, At noontide they grope as at night.
So the needy He saves from the sword, And the poor from the hands of the mighty.
Thus hope is born in the weak, And iniquity stoppeth her mouth.
Happy then the mortal whom God correcteth: So spurn no thou the Almighty’s chastening.
For He bindeth the wounds He hath made, And His hands heal the hurt He hath dealt.
He will save thee in six distresses, In seven no evil shall touch thee.
In famine He frees thee from death, And in war from the power of the sword.
From the scourge of tongue thou art safe; Thou shalt fear not the onslaught of ruin.
At ruin and dearth shalt thou laugh, And the beasts of the field thou shalt fear not.
For the stones of the earth are thine allies, The beasts of the field are thy friends.
Thou shalt know that thy tent is secure, Thou shalt visit thy fold and miss nothing.
Thy seed thou shalt know to be many, Thine offspring as grass of the earth.
Thou shalt come to the grave in thy strength, As a sheaf cometh in its season.
See! this we have searched – so it is. We have heard it – lay thou it to heart. Job’s Denunciation of Hollow Friendship. His Challenge of God and His Longing to be Gone
